text: Bottle--thanks, Probstblueribbon. Potent brown sugar and sherry aroma with lots of strawberry jam. Hazy brick dark orange under a thin, white collar. Sweet rich malt flavour with dark toasted bread and some strawberry jelly with low bitterness. Medium full body, moderate carbonation, smooth. Overly sweet.

Undated 750mL bottle shared by Brian on 10/15/16. Probably a few years old at this point.Still very nicely carbonated with a big, off-white head that is well-retained, topping a cherry-tinted auburn-golden body with good clarity.Oxidation is very apparent in the nose, but its not of the cardboard type. Rather, dates, vanilla, cherries, almonds and such arise having blended with the varied fruity malt notes, caramel and toffee sugars spicy phenols and light earthiness of the yeast. More fruitiness as it warms in the form of apples, cherries and pears, with big vanilla notes from the oxidation. No alcohol or flaw.Fairly sweet in the mouth though the oxidation somewhat works against that. Definitely not underattenuated, though, and malty as many true BdGs are. Big fruity notes, lots of vanilla and medium-dry caramel, with yellow fruits, spicy phenols and earthy, mineral-laden notes from the yeast. Malty texture with strong, but mostly tight carbonation and no alcohol or flaw. Cool, been a long while since I thought of Schlafly and this was a fun one to see. Thanks, Brian.
75CL, Thanks WillRun. Reddish orange, slightly hazy. no head. Smells like a watery orange peel with gatorade. Sweet flavor. Candi sugar, mango, oranges, very sweet. peppery finish.

750 ml bottle shared by Willrunforbeer. Orange in color, thin bubbly head. Aroma is delicate, bread, sugar, and light oxidation. 
Flavor is yeasty and bready. Dried fruits, honey, orange peel, mild cardboard. 
Light oxidation but to be fair, this is well over a year old. I will grade on a slight curve.
750ml bottle from trade. Pours orange brown gold with an off white head. Aroma is multigrain bread, caramel. Flavor is caramel, rock candy, light grains. This is sweet, but the flavor is quite nice.

750 ml bottle from Artale in Rockford, IL, served at cellar temp in a Duvel glass. Big, fluffy, lasting head leaves chunky lace atop the dusky dark amber body...big expressive nose is cidery/tart, spicy, fairly funky/yeasty, quite potent...on the tongue, also quite cidery and tart, very acidic at the front, with notes of sweet-tart cherries as well, pale malts coming through eventually along with a lactic sourness that is fortunately restrained...finish is relatively drier though the fruitiness never abates, and faintly peppery/alcoholic...moderately full body, aggressive carbonation. Its been a while since Ive had a traditional BDG, so I cant say that Im qualified to suggest whether this is "true" to style or not; seems more tart/sour and fruity than I remember being typical. Pretty decent on the whole though I feel its going to be an effort to get through this whole bottle alone.

Bottle, about a year old, from Michael (misterburd) -- cheers, buddy! I love a good Bière de Garde, but they get a bad rap sometimes: theyre sweet, caramel-y, and biscuit in a world that seems to go nuts for whatevers the latest hop bomb. This has a lot of the great malt flavor of a classic BdG, but the yeast added a Belgian Abbey ale flavor and aroma. It surprised me, but not really in a bad way. It just ended up tasting like a combination of a Bière de Garde and a Trappist beer.
Nose of malt with lactic. Malty and mellow bitter. Tootsie pop chocolate. Yum.

Aroma of earthy malt and yeast. Murky tangerine color with a small head. No real lacing. Full and weighty. More malty Flavors with an earthy and barnyard aftertaste. Some hints of fruit tartness. Low hop presence.
Bottled. 9/4/12. Hazy dark brown yellow. Taste is a wired mix of raisins, pears, floral.
Sample at Hopfest 2015. Comes a cloudy golden orange with a nice white head. Aroma of fruit, yeast, and spice. Taste is citrus, yeast, fruit, spice, and malt. Pretty good.

Bottle to glass. Pours a cloudy orangish light amber color with a frothy off white head. Aroma is mildly tart, fruity, barnyard funk. Flavor has a good balance between tart, funk, and belgian yeast. Very nice.

tea colored with a lot of suspension and about an inch and a half of tan foam, hanging for a while; smells like lemon, yeasty funk, orange, oak, toast; a bit astringent with apple, some caramel, and toasty bitterness; medium palate that hold up very well; Super yummy, Im somewhat skeptical of the style usually but this is almost like a saison, but lacks the peppery qualities.
Musty fruity sour apple flavor. Tart and mold funk character, really good brew with lots of nuances from fruit to funk to woodyness.

Brown bottle, 1 pint 9.4 ounces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on November 11 2014; eye: orangey with a caramel hue, hazy, thin sheet of tan head that turns into a tiny ring, light lacing; nose: malt, grain, slight fruity; mouth: malt, light sourish, grain, slight fruity, lightly sourish finale with slight presence of caramel, medium-light body, good carbonation, slightly sweet; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 9,4 onces, 7,0 %, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 11 novembre 2014; il : orangée avec une teinte caramel, trouble, mince couverture de mousse fauve qui se transforme en un petit anneau, légère dentelle; nez : malt, grain, très léger fruité; bouche : malt, léger aigrelet, grain, très léger fruité, finale légèrement aigrelette avec très légère présence de caramel, corps moyen-léger, bonne carbonatation, très légèrement sucrée; en résumé : correct
Thick foamy head. Malty flavors with a touch of apricot. Golden color. Somewhat sweet with a slight fizziness. Good--not my idea of a Belgian farmhouse ale but an ale, yes
Split a 750ml bottle. Poured a dark orange color with a medium sized fluffy-white head. Aroma was light spices, light floral notes, some malt notes. Flavor was floral, sweet malt, funky yeast notes.
Bottle. Hazy orange pour with a big soapy head. Bready, toffee, mild pineapple. Smooth palate. Maybe a touch flat, but not bad.

Bottle. Hazy dark orange/ amber. Fruity yeast aroma with grains and biscuit. The taste follows adding spiced apple and apricot, rich malts, toffee, and a little lemon. Very complex overall. Interesting style. Good stuff. Im glad I tried this one.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours orangish with a white head. Taste sweet, Carmel, bready. I thought this was good. I could drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From old notes, tasted with Curtis and some friends in Nashville, probably some time near the summer of 2012, from a 750mL bottle. Pours cloudy dark orange with an average white head that leaves a thin collar of lace. The nose is pretty strange pumpkin and peanut brittle with a bit of yeast spice. The flavor is more or less the same, a touch of sweet peanut brittle toffee, a fruity and somewhat vegetal pumpkin, and some yeast spice. The body is full with average, stinging carbonation, and a long lightly sweet peanut brittle finish.

16oz growler pours a hazy pineapple orange with some creamy, swirling white head. Nose has quite a bit of bubblegum and clove, some tropical fruit too, some candy, some straw. Flavor is candy sweet, some mango, some dried pineapple chunks, bubblegum, a little anise too. Sticky finish. I get that the style is a bit of a catch all, but this had way to much wit character for me. I was expecting something with a bit more of a malt backbone and more subdued yeast components.

A light amber color with a white head. Aroma contains some caramel, citrus, and skittles. The flavor is malty with a bittersweet finish. I just taste some caramel, biscuit, lemon. Its refreshing and complex. I dig it.

Bottle: Poured a clear deep orangey color ale with a small foamy head with minimal retention and no lacing. Aroma of grainy cereal notes with quite a bit of residuals sugars. Taste is also a mess with an overload of residual sugars and some grainy cereal notes with some funny ester. Body is semi-full with medium-to-low carbonation. Incredible mess with a definite lack of attenuation.

Bottled with love on 22812, so Im sure this one has gotten the requisite time to "meld together nicely", as per its own claim. 25.4oz, just a crown. Nose is sweet and floral, vanilla and cream, pale malt, very nice and dessert-like, faint fruit with smooth and really nice yeast. Some great jammy fruit, also strong phenols that are pushing toward solvent a bit too quickly. Pours clear, deep red with orange low-lights around the edges, supports a dense and foamy beige head with above-average carbonation. Taste is sweet, jammy fruit with low bitterness, average sweetness; not really tart or tangy, but waves of developed and layered malt; faint spicy character within the pleasant and calm breadiness; alcohol fully tamed except for the slow-developing warmth in the chest. Hay, lightly floral, faint citrus, and just incredible balance!  Very light body but isnt watery, malt is too well advanced for that. Yeast here is very much like that of one of my favorites, Unibroue, as is the fruitiness. Smooth and lovely, what a wonderful surprise!

Bottle from Finger Lakes Beverage Co. (best beer store in Upstate NY, IMHO). Farmhouse nose: lots of hay and straw, freshness. Gorgeous appearance, hazy and not too filtered. Banana and hoppy notes, tastes like a boozy saison.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Mastikim. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours orange to brown with a nice head, aroma of honey, caramel, toffee, alcohol, brandy, flavor of malt, caramel, toffee, honey and brandy, medium bodied.
Strong nose and mild taste. Pours a murky orange color. probably wouldnt buy again but worth trying.

Draft:
Hazy golden yellow with a small white head.
Slightly funky..pear aroma.
Sweet apple, pear, lactic flavour.
Very nice!
1 pt. 9.4 fl.oz. bottle @ One Pint Pub. Pours murky amber with a low head. Aroma is sour malts with some yeast. Flavor is sour malts and some yeast. Very nice.
Draft. Lactic lemon malt aroma. Golden yellow with moderate head. Sweet milky lemon malt and hay flavor. Very nice.

750 ml bottle poured into a teku. Pours a clear copper with a white head of foam. The aroma is really pretty malty and earthy. Not much in the way of a hop profile. The taste is woody and sweet. Medium body and medium carbonation.

Rated on 12-02-2009 (Bottle) This beer pours a large frothy off-white head with a short retention, transparent gold body, slow rising carbonation, and one ring of lacing. The Aroma is malty, slightly yeasty, sweet, tart, and fruity. The Taste is sweet, sour, tart, malty, fruity, and has a short dry finish. The Palate is tingly and this is a medium bodied beer. Overall, this beer is quaffable, worth trying and a beer I would consider drinking again.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Mastikim. Thanks beerandbeyond. Deep orange-amber color. Aroma of malt, caramel, some fruitiness, cookie notes and light yeasty notes. Sweetish flavor, malty, fruity, a bit caramelly, with light sourness, yeast and some spiciness, especially in the finish. Medium-bodied. So-so.
750ml bottle pours a copper orange with a large white head. Sweet caramel malts aroma. Apple spice with pear taste. Great beer.

Elle est belle, orangée, limpide, une mousse la recouvre et prends son temps pour se résorber. Elle devient trouble au second versage. Du malt, du sucre dorge, des fruits; de la poire et de la pêche font office dodeurs. Un goût de levure, de poivre, avec un côté sucré et ce nest pas mémorable. La minceur est inattendue. ce qui reste en bouche, cest le côté poivré, amalgamé au sucre. Je ne sais pas trop quoi en penser? Elle nest pas remarquable, elle semble même artificielle. (854-111013)

750 ml bottle from Blue Dog Lansdale, Whole Foods PM. Pours hazy dark straw with off-white head. Nose is caramel malt, yeasty tart fruit, mild funk and hopcitrus. Finishes cobwebby estery, dry, and funky.

Draft to taster. Looks good for the style; a slightly cloudy golden orange with foamy off-white head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells sweet and yeasty with a bit of tartness. Tastes like it smells with a bit of spices and an average mouthfeel. Not bad.

750 ml bottle. Cloudy orange amber color with a small beige head. Nice clinging lace. Fragrant toasted malt aroma with notes of cinnamon and coconut. Tangy toasted malt flavor is redolent of tropical fruit and sweet caramel. Light floral hops balance the residual malty sweetness. Sweet cloying malt in finish and aftertaste.

No bottling information.
Appearance: The body is a dark amber with poor clarity. The head is dense and rather tall, but dissipates rather quickly into a bubbly light tan coating.
Aroma: The aroma is malty and a bit musky, Im guessing this is old. I am smelling hints of fruitiness, but its hard to discern, perhaps orange and strawberry with a hint of bubblegum. 
Taste: Banana and strawberry are prominent with big malts of caramel and a cereal sweetness. Dried fig is noticed towards the finish with a light peppery spice thats strongest by the finish.
Palate: Medium bodied with moderate to high carbonation.
Overall: I enjoy this, but its certainly a bit older than it probably should be. I would love to try this fresh and see how the malts interact with the fruitiness and spiciness of this.

Bottle 750 ml 
 Aroma:  caramel, tartness, fresh hop fell. Slight mineral vibe to it. Refreshing with authentic feel to it. 7+
 Appearance:  poured murky amber in color with larger off white cap. Sparse lacing.3+
 Palate / Taste:  Softer front, bready malts, hint of caramel. Some vanilla like hints. Sweeter finish. Nice dinner table choice.

Bouteille de 75 cl. embouteillée le 19 décembre 2012, bue en compagnie de SlovakSniper. Bière dorée foncée à la limite du ambrée. Au nez des notes de caramel, de fruits et dépices. En bouche le liquide a une belle texture huileuse, les saveurs épicées sont agréables mais un peu trop sucré. Agréable.

Un flacon de 75 cl. Un liquide embouteillé avec amour le 19 décembre 2012. Une robe ambrée. Un anneau de mousse. Un nez de caramel fruité et de grains roux avec un léger parfum suret et presque épicé. Un goût légèrement granuleux mais aussi doucement malté avec des fruits pâles et quelque chose dépicé qui peut sans doute être attribuable aux levures. Une touche herbeuse comme un signe évident des houblons. Une bouche de moyenne densité avec un pétillement vers le bas et une texture à la limite huileuse. Une finale plutôt sèche et faiblement épicée.
Poured from a brown bottle. Murky orange brown color, nice white head, good lacing. Slight sour, bitter, farmhouse smell. slight breaded taste, fruit taste.

The aroma is lightly reminiscent of sweet dough yeast and sour fruit, and the appearance is a cloudy orange color with a small head. The taste is mildly sour and mildly sweet, which creates a nice balanced flavor, and the palate fuses a medium body, thin and slick texture, soft carbonation, and a sour and slightly astringent finish.

750 mL bottle from Beer Run. Pours a hazy copper color with a thin creamy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of toffee, caramel, earthy notes and a dry fruitiness. The taste is bready malts, caramel, herbal hops, mild spice. Medium bodied.

Bottle shared at Saint Somewhere Brewing.  Pours a hazy brown-amber color with a white head.  Nose is some bready malts, some slight earth, and some fruit.  Flavor is similar with some fruity notes, some bready malt, and some dryness to the finish.  Nice bier de garde.

Appearance: clear copper, with a short, fizzy near white head and minimal lacing.   Aroma: rustic brown bread, poppyseed, caramel, a hint of cherry lifesaver candies, and some lime zest.   Taste: as the aroma indicates, with a bit of yeasty/basement funk and a good dollop of floral honey.   Finish: slightly sweet and chewy, with lingering caramel malts.   Notes: On the sweet side for a biere de garde, but tasty enough.  Better than average.

On tap; publicity pub in Bellevue Tn; nice farmhouse Saison.  Great springtime-summer brew.  Lemon/fruit taste.  Good stuff.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
750ml bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with little to no head.Delicious aroma of citrus, Belgian  yeast, and spices. Taste is funky. Malty, yeasty and some spice (coriander and clove).

75 cl bottle @ HBF2010.
Originally rated on 20100409.
Pours clear golden color with a small head. Aroma of fruits, mild hops, herbs, grass and pale malts. Flavor of herbs, hay, mild fruits, hops and malts. Decent.
750 mL bottle. Pours a golden color with white head. Grainy, straw, honey aromas. Belgian yeast, slightly tangy, and bread flavors. Pretty solid biere de garde.

Bottle at the Funky 8, Brooklyn, NYC. Nice and bready. Some caramel, light fruits, spices and yeast. I can understand why some folks dont like this style, but I think this is a good example of biere de garde at its best.

Cloudy dark orange amber, rim head, bands of lace.  Taste is caramel malt with citrus fruit and spices, a fairly rich combination.  Taste grows through the palate and adds a light bittering, finishes with a return to malt.  Somewhat filling; alcohol is well hidden; a well-executed brew.

Draft - pours like hazy honey wot white head and thin lacing. Nose is yeast and hay. Flavor adds bread, alcohol, lemon peel, and caramel. Sweet with subtle bitterness. Perhaps a honey aftertaste. Bitterness is more apparent as beer warms. Reminds me of Le Merle. Medium body. Latent sourness.
Hazy orange, loose white head. Smells sicy and lightly fruity. Seems very hearty. Taste is bready, toasty, with a hint of pear and white wine, plus some funky flavors. Pretty tasty.

On tap. Murky amber-copper with a small covering of bubbles. Nose is light funky grape skin, lemony yeast, earthy spice, and oxidized apple. Tastes of rusty apple, clove bubblegum, white wine and grape must. Light-medium body has low carbonation and is well balanced by a dry finish.
Enjoyed at a @JaxBrewBitch bottle share at Brewers pizza in Jacksonville,FL... This one was nice and balanced, would have liked a little more WOW factor.

750 ml bottle poured a clear orange amber with a lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, earthiness, light barnyard, yeast and a hint of citrus. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of straw, earthiness, light yeast and light spice with a smooth lingering earthy finish.
Draught->tulip.  Light amber with white head.  Yeast and malt with some grains and spice.  Nice citrus notes.  Very good.

Enjoyed from tap #40 at the iTap House (Chesterfield) and poured into a Wide Chalice.

Appearance- Bronze color and shiny cloud with great retention. The head was very minimal but then became a small circle in the middle of the beer.

Smell- Fruit from the first whiff, and then smelled an entirely different smell of hops.

Taste- A great flavor of fruit, and almost sour like a sour kriek. There was a sweetness that overpowered all senses but discovered this to be a more complexed biere than I thought. Maybe could be classified as a Saison?

Mouthfeel- Sour taste at the end of experience with a Medium Bodied base. 

Drinkability- I enjoyed every part of this beer and will be promoting it to other curious drinkers from the iTap house. Now this is my favorite beer from Schlafly! Could enjoy 3-4 more but had to leave the bar because of our blizzard scare throughout St. Louis news and television station interruptions.

Sample from beerfest. Poured a darker orange color with a nicer two finger head. Left lacing as it went. Aroma was fruits, spice, and some citrus notes. Flavor was funk, spices, pear, and some other malty mash. Average mouthfeel. Finishes with spice and malt. Medium body. Decent beer.

June 26, 2012 - on tap at the Schlafly tap house.  Dark orange pour with minimal head.  Aroma of spice, fruit and yeast.  Taste was consistent with a malty finish.  Medium bodied and some carbonation.
Bottle split with Annie, pours a hazy, glowing orange, small to med white head with decent lace. Aromas and taste of apple crisp, dark fruits, sweet malt, orange peel, and a nice belgian yeast.

750ml bottle poured into a tulip. Bottled 2/4/2011. Pours a lightly hazy dark orange with minimal head. Aroma is mostly spicy yeast with a little citrus. Taste is light sweet. Caramel, wheat and some citrus. Medium bodied with a creamy and sticky texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, great. I would love to drink it again.

On tap at Jaleo in downtown Washington, DC. 

Clear, bright dark copper orange with 2-finger tan head and good lacing. 

Aroma of sweet malt, funky yeast, apple pear and spice. 

Taste of sweet malt and fruit with mild yeast and spice flavors.  A rather complex mix of flavors that dance around in your mouth with different flavors alternating for the leading role. 

Medium body and above average carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours perfumed mildly spicy, with a soapy headed medium golden body.  Very smooth drinker, The citrus and pleasantly spicy taste was excellent on a hot night. Soft mouthfeel.
Beautiful copper color, lots of breadiness with a nice fruity accent, really enjoying this.

Pours a hazy light amber with a big foamy head. The aroma is quite malty with some bread. The taste has the bread, a bit of fruit along with a slight lemon sourness. A bit thin. Finishes dry and refreshing.

From the big bottle poured a copper colored brew with a fluffy white head. Fruity, malty aromas, oh, yes, did I mention malty aromas. Fruity, kind of melony, and malty flavors. If you dont like malty flavors, you wont like this one.

Bottle. Hazy copper with foamy white dissipating head. Smells like fruit and vanilla and a tart note. Tastes sweet but with a light bitterness and dryness following and then a hint of fruit on the finish. Never had a biere de garde before- not my favorite beer, but Ill drink it!

Lovely- sweet, refreshing, very floral and perfumey. The beer had great fizziness to it that was sharp and slightly acidic,making it much more enjoyable given the heat outside. Sampled at the second annual East Nashville Beer Festival.
Bottle - small foamy head, hazy dark straw color, pretty tart/sour fruit aroma, fruity flavor with only mild tartness (not as much as you would think from the aroma), well balanced

Clear orange-copper with decent, foamy, beige head / Mild, delicate, earthy nose of bread, spun sugar, and citrus / Medium body, somewhat syrupy, sweetly malty with only light hopping, and good finish / Flavors of honey, spun sugar, orange peel, resin, and grass / More towards the cloying side of the spectrum that I would prefer, but still a fine brew.

Bread and a mix of fruit/sweetness/tartness in aroma.  The flavor is bubble gum, yeast, bananas, a hint of spice and a mildly tart finish.  The complexity and subtlety of this worked very well in the flavor.

A cloudy, dark yellow orange beer with a huge frothy white head.  The aroma is fruity with a lot of lemon and yeast.  The flavor is slightly tart and fruity with a nice malty sweetness and a medium body.

for my 600th! review I rate this minnow.  Was free so I shouldnt complain but its not good.  Doughy citrus and cardboard dominate.  I would say maybe its old? but its a biere de garde so thats supposed to be a good quality.  Off flavors and strange sweetness are everywhere.
This is fucking gross. Drunk Rizy wont even drink it. Thatll fuxking tell you something.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 From the 2/2012 3R6P tasting. +++ Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer poured a murky orange-caramel color with a trace white head that faded quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was bready with a faint musty and citric undertone. The flavor was tart citrus and bread with undertones that were musty and dusty. The finis was medium length and dry with a bit of citrus, must and bread. Medium body. Ok.

Bottle- Pours a copper color with a fluffy head that fades to good lacing.
 Mild aroma of fruit, bit of spice and caramel to round it out. Initially tangy with a mixture of fruit and bit of caramel. There is a mild bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body, Crisp and refreshing with a bit of alcohol warming. Very well balanced. Very nice for the style. I can see having this from time to time. I would like to try this after it has aged for a while.

On tap at the bottleworks.  Spice and sweet malt aroma.  Orange-gold with off-white head.  Great balance of esters (not really to style, but nice here), spice and biscuit malt (true to style).  Burnt fruit with medium mouthfeel.

Pour is a nice orange color with a small bone white head. Nose is rather fruity, with a little barnyard in there as well. Taste is very similar to the nose with a little bit of booze on the backside. Not bad oerall.

Poured from 750 obtained in a trade.  Cloudy goldish-yellow with a nice white head. Nose was sweet fruit and caramel. Taste was on the sweet malty side, good mouthfeel, full bodied with good carbonation.  Dont try a lot of these, but very enjoyable.

Bottle shared at the December iteration of the Santa Cruz tasting series. Pours dark bronze with a small white head. Aromas of bruised apples and old caramel/stale bread. Unfiltered apple juice in the flavor, bready and honeyed, tart fruitiness, medium bitterness. Tastes old.

75cl bottle. Big fruity and malty nose with an earthy apple quality. Seemingly some neutral to beneficial oxidation giving some honey and dried fruit, but I didnt think this was that old. Perhaps aged before release? Still has a good amount of bitterness to it. Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Seems pretty typical of the style, if we could call it a style, or at least our idea of it. Not bad but I cant say that I really like it. Too much earthy apple and malt sweetness for me.

Pours hazy orange with small what fizz. Smells like funky, a bit like hay, a little tart and a touch bitter. Taste is lacking in flavor, but is just generally funky; nothing is WRONG with it, just is not as flavorful as it should be. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and decent mouth-carbonation, Schlafly Bière de Garde finishes with a little bitter funkiness.

Poured into a tulip.

4.0 A: Hazed medium orange color. Three fingers of pillowy off-white head. Retention is average and a good amount of irregular lacing is left.

4.0 S: Doughy/bready maltiness with a hint of unfermented wort. Toasty with caramel. Quite fruity with peach, apples, and pear. Light apple orchard type funk. Peppery with subtle phenols. Quite pleasant.

4.0 T: Fruitiness is most prominent with apple, pear, peach, and orange in descending intensity. Doughy malts with breadiness coming from the yeast. Again, toasty with light caramel notes. Apple orchard and hay funkiness.

5.0 M: Lighter medium body. Perhaps a touch more carbonation than I would have expected but it works well. Extremely creamy. Perfect here.

4.5 D: Tasty beer throughout. All flavors complement each other extremely well. Solid.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-16-2011 05:23:51

Aroma of dough, butterscotch, lemon and citrus. Appearance was amber with bone head. Flavor of butterscotch, dough and caramel up front, but with a citrus finish. Palate was bubbly and the mouth feel a bit big for the style. This felt sorta like an amped up BDG, but I liked it.

tap at taproom and a few bottles over the years-pours dark orange with a small fizy white head.  nose is fruity, estery with a hint of dry green grapes.  flavors are spicy with lite sweetness, earthy tones with mild zest quality.  The bottles i remember having were a bit more on the sweet side than this.  the spices here really dry the beer out, which is good.  long grainy finish with lingering sweetness and spice.  decent beer however, i dont know this style all that well, so i cant compare it to others.
From a bottle poured an amber color with a small amount of head.  Sweet malty flavor with a lingering finish.

750 ml bottle. Bought at Schlafly in 2007. I think this ones ready! Pours a big fruity ester smell into a Stella glass. Tangy orange beer color, pretty clean looking, and a ring of foam around the edge as remnants of a puffy headed pour. Taste is full of big fruit flavor, a little cider, some pear and a note of plum. Bracketed around this is some green apple tartness and a bit of funk. Yep, a definite thread of a Belgian sour ale in there, and its all for the good. Hops are in the background, as might be expected, and add to the malt "forward-i-ness" of the beer. Pouring further from the bottle brings up more haze in the beer, as I stir up the yeast in the bottom. The bottle conditioning gives a nearly champagne like effervescence, albeit at a lower pressure and with less risk of frothing over. I believe I paid $7.50 for this big boy at Schlafly Bottleworks. Bet you cant sneeze at it for that price now.

Tasted on-tap 9/17/2011 at the Hop in the City Festival in a clean half-pint taster glass. An interesting historical French style: basically a cold-aged farmhouse ale which many consider the best balance of clean/rough characteristics. Nice orange color. Medium body. High percentage of alcohol, Though not exactly a fault, Schlaflys example is probably too cleaned-up (likely to appease casual beer drinkers.) Sadly lacking any of the rougher farmhouse or cellar aspects. Good but not great.
It poured a hazy golden color with a white head. The flavor was spicy. The taste was light, some fruitiness, spicy and some sweetness. A  very decent Biere de Garde.

bottle at old chicago Pours deep amber/mahogony with good head and retention. Aromas are floral, fruity, with striong spices, and some hopping.Flavours are strong spices, almost curry-ish and dark fruity hops bitterness. Lots of sugars in the finish, with nice lingering spicy pumpkin-seed bitterness.

750ml, 2010 vintage consumed in early 2011.  Pours a clear dark golden to light copper hue with a thick, spongy head of off-white to beige foam.  Ever so slowly, the cap recedes to a thin but lasting film, leaving dense clumps and rings of lacing that cling hard to the glass.  The aroma is nice, displaying a surprisingly spicy profile of wild florals and peppery sandalwood in the foreground, then shifting towards malty dough and toasted nuts glazed with honey.  The spicy notes provide a nice, sharp pop on the nose, cutting through the sweet (but not overly so) malts, which now include lightly toasted marshmallow.  Flavors lean a bit more towards the bready, doughy side of things, as round, fruity yeast starts to throw its weight around.  Still, a persistent, woody spiciness shows through, along with faded floral hops and various other spices.  Trace mineral elements add a surprisingly nice, earthy edge that compliments the floral hopping.  Theres fairly nice balance overall.  The palate also manages to tow the line well, initially whipped and creamy, then sharpening up a bit with focused carbonation before ending just a bit overly sticky for my tastes.  On the whole, Id say this is a very nicely executed American interpretation of a bière de garde.  Back it down to 6% and dry it out just a tad and Id say this would approach top tier status for the genre.  As i stands, its a nice bottle to split two ways amongst friends.  Id gladly try it again.

Once more I find myself in the position of having just read about a particular beer style and then writing a review about it. The beer in particular is the Biere de Garde from Schlafly. The beer style in question is the French version of the Belgian Saison, or farmhouse ale.


Cloudy tan with rustic hues of old hay and straw while scattered bunches of bubbles lazily skim the surface. No amount of coaxing is going to make this head linger, and why should it when the nose beckons with straight-forward urgency. A quick slap of tart, sour funk leads immediately into grass, bailed hay, crisp straw, leather, and the earthly essence of barnyard dust. I close my eyes and I am in a field of hay, the breeze rustling their pointy tips while in the distance a homely barn can be seen beckoning. Not ready to open my eyes yet, there must be fresh fruit orchards nearby as tart plums, peaches, and tangerines join the breeze. Amidst her resplendent bouquet is an underpinning of brown sugar and nutmeg for a sprinkling of spice. It would be rather dangerous to partake of my Biere de Garde with eyes closed, and so I leave the immediate comfort of her aura to dive deep into her embrace. Clean, clear, and immediately tart with far more sour funk than I initially expected. I wouldnt put her on the level of a lambic or gueze, but a distant cousin maybe. Riding the way of dry sourness are crisp peaches, tangerines, and nectarines, all with a healthy dose of crisp skin. A bite lingers in the back of my throat with citric acidity while nutmeg, cinnamon, and brown sugars linger long into my breath. Each quaff is deliciously refreshing with a dazzling array of vivid flavors. She grows a bit more earthen further in as some barnyard dust and leather settles into her palate. My glass drained, I close my eyes once more so I may relive for just a while longer the harder yet simpler times where a long day in the fields was relieved by the simple pleasure of a Biere de Garde, chunk of bread, a slab of fresh cheese, and maybe some pickled onions.


Maybe there is a reason why, even now, it is the simplest of pleasures for which we derive the most self-satisfaction. I will take fresh baked bread and decadent cheese with my beer any day, and could enjoy a meal of just those three. While France still holds the key to authentic Biere de Garde, I would be hard-pressed to note many other American craft brewers who were able to accomplish a little bit of French history in a bottle as well as Schlafly has done.

Taste is sweet honey caramel maltiness mostly, floral white pepper spiciness behind that.  Yeasty.  Palate is medium, grainy, with a fair amount of carbonation.  Interesting, and well done.
Thanks to PhillyBeer for the taste.  Aroma is apples and caramel.  Flavor follows suit with caramel apples and a slight citrus bitterness.
Pours copper color with off white head. Bready aroma. Sweet caramel flavor with some citrus notes and fruitiness. Medium body with average carbonation. Pretty good beer.

750ml bottle. Dark orange pour with a thin white head. Aroma is like opening a can of tomatoes, a little pepper spicyness as well. Smooth flavor, not tomatoes though. Very slight sweetness , not overwhelming, pretty good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Candied fruit, orange peel nose. Touches of grassy hop? Bright copper gold color. Modest head. Sweet candy flavors, sugary. Little spicy alcoholic kick in the finish. Very sweet.
Poured a light  amber with a abig white head. Spicy yeasty aroma. Flavor is aged hops, yeasty malt, and light citrus.
Hazy amber with a white head. Doughy, yeasty aromas with dry hay. Smooth frothy mouthfeel. Good dusty pale malt flavors with earthy hay and grass. Turns lightly sweet as it warms. Nice beer.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle bonused in trade from xmarcnolanx and shared at a tasting.  Thanks man.  Pours a glowing orange clear color with a whitish head.  Smell is spiced with coriander and orange peel.  Taste is crisp orange peel, sweet malt, spiced yeast and it drops off a bit though and finishes dull and abruptly.  A bit too sweet as well after a while.  Drinkable, but gets lost in the shuffle.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2008 750 ml bottle (The Wine and Cheese Place Clayton)- Pours a nice orangish amber with a nice full head that diminishes into a small covering. Aroma of Belgian yeast, grains, clove, banana, and some citrus. Taste begins with clove, banana, yeast, and some spices. This medium bodied brew is quite well balanced and delicious. Yummy

750ml bottle: Intersting presentation for Schlafly - I am not sure how the bright green lettering and orange cap fit in with the brewery, but the bottles sure jump out on the shelf. The beer pours a cloudy amber with a smallish white cap. The nose is hard to pick apart - very musty and grainy. The body was the same to me, with lots of mustiness overriding the nice layering of sweet malt. There is a noticeable layer of hoppiness that keeps the beer lively and not compeltey in grandma’s cellar. Enjoyable, but I am not a fan of the style.

Bottle. Spicy with notes of funk, this is an interesting biere de garde. Hazy golden body with a big, white head that is mostly lasting. The aroma presents notes of clove, pepper, grain, mustiness, dust and hints of toast and citrus. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. The beer finishes moderately bitter and dry. Medium body with a somewhat grainy texture. Lively carbonation. Enjoyable.

Bottle. Spicy-bready aroma with light peach and musk. Bright cloudy amber with a thin head. Very light biscuit and spice. Full bodied with a slightly tart aftertaste. Nice texture and good carbonation.

Picked up a 750mL bottle from the Schlafly brewery downtown.  Pours a nice amber color with a very solid 2 inch head which sticks around and is probably the highest carbonated beer I have ever seen.  Aroma has a sweet apricot fruitiness, some spicy hints of cloves, graham cracker and a very soured acidic aroma at the end of all the smells.  The beer tastes totally different from what the aroma is hinting at.  Flavor is very very rich and smooth and starts with a sweet candy sugar flavor with a hint of vanilla.  It has a very fast appearance of cherry Sucrets cough drops in the middle but moves directly into a biscuit heavy flavor and ends with a slightly alcohol  mixed with gingerbread flavor. Beer leaves great lacing in the glass.  Complex smells and flavors really make this beer unique.  A definite must try!

I liked this one a lot. All that brought it down were the weak aroma and watery palate, both of which will probably be improved with time. Pours a nice looking orange, with a thin head and minimal lacing. Flavor is complex, but drinkable.  Hops, a nice funk, slight bitterness, some spice in the background.  Some booziness and astringentness. Almost a touch of smokey meat. A candy like sugar finish. Dry, but a little too sticky.  I liked the flavor of this one a lot.

Bottle from Wine and Cheese Place in (near) St. Louis, MO. Pours hazy bright amber with a nice beige head. Aromas of sugary caramel and a light touch of funk. Medium body with frothy/creamy carbonation. Flavor is slightly barnyard, over roasted malt and some spice. More malt than most Biere de Gardes. It is fruity, and it finishes towards the dry side. Very chewy and tasty. Leaves a very good result in the mouth.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2008 750 mL bottle that I purchased while up in MI this summer-put a year on it, and I’ll try it now.  Served in snifter- poured transparent dark amber with copper tints, there was light carbonation and a small foamy white head.  Aroma of toffee, a very slightly roasted malt, and caramel hit my nose.  Hit my mouth with a high-medium body, middle has bit of a heavy note while wheat and very slightly roasted barley hit the tongue.  Yep.

I just don’t understand, I have had this beer 3 times now, three separate bottles and they have bee all bad.  And its not that I just don’t like it, I am pretty sure its the damn DMS or maybe its some nasty phenols (but I think its DMS), either way all three bottles have had it and I know I can’t be the only picking it up.  Its there and its in the way.  Otherwise looks fine, dark amber and cloudy.

text: Cloudy orange pour with creamy white tight head and lace. Nose of light bronw sugar and light clove. Flavor mirrors aroma. Medium bodied with good mouthfeel and carbonation. Pretty nice

Bottle from the kind generosity of gueuze_is_god.  Jeez, this is good.  Bright hazy amber pour with one-finger off-white head that dies down to almost nothing.  Nose deftly combines tart and malty... think shortbread cookies with apricot jelly.  A sly metallic soapy note in there as well, but it doesn’t do much damage--comes across more floral.  Sour woody/earthy notes as well.  Really lovely aroma.  More fruit and malt on the tongue, and a nice mouthfeel even with the lack of head.  I really like this beer.

Draught at Saint Louis Brewery Schlafly.  Pours hazy amber with an average, fizzy, off-white head, somewhat lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toffee), average hops (flowers, herbs), average yeast (barnyard, earth) with notes of date and apple.  Medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a chalky finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness.

Bottle shared by someone at the Shenandoah Beer Throwdown, thanks someone!!  Dark orange color, with a fizzy champagne head.  Aroma is soapy, fruity, yeasty.  Flavor similar, with pepper, tart, slightly tangy.

750ml bottle.  Golden color with easily stirred up carbonation. Aroma has biscuit with notes of citrus and grass.  Flavor was very similar to the aroma.  With light biscuit, citrus and grassiness.  Great to enjoy while sitting around/in the pool.  Body was quenching and medium.  This was the surprise of the day for me.

Big white head on a cloudy orange/amber body.  Minerally, dry, dusty yeast nose, earthy toast everywhere.  Peppery orange and bread crust tasted up front; soft body, smooth up front, with a bite on the back fresh, dusty, earthy yeast throughout, tasty fruit and honey in a lingering finish.  Well-made.

750ml bottle from MO. Pours a clear golden copper with a thin near white head with no lacing. Light aroma of earthly malt, fruit, and bread. Flavors hold suit to the aroma with the yeast character standing out which start subdued and build to the nice dry finish. Med light body, very lively carb,light creamy texture, and dry feel. I didn’t know what to expect from this brew, but was very happy with the result. Aroma was light and a little heavy on the carbonation, although they did not distract from the beer and even improved as the bottle sat and warmed before my next glass.

750 served slightly chilled into a Duvel produces a hazy amber body with a creamy almond head. Aroma is herbal and minty with a strong caramel undertone. Creamy medium body with a lively carbonation. Taste is dry and herbal. Solid malt backbone yields up strong caramel notes. Only a trace of funkiness. Quite well done, but nothing screams exceptional. Perhaps, some aging will bring out some needed character.

750 from ASymon13 on BA - thanks, Andrew! A very handsome pour, full bodied with a significant head and a lovely orange color. Visible yeast and sediment (including what looked like a couple flakes of oregano). The aroma was fairly weak, although once you get into the beer it emerges as a nice combination of yeasty, bready malts, some well rounded fruits (apricot in particular), and a trace of spice. Nice creamy palate, and a decent finish.
Lightly foggy amber, with a nice off white head.  Aroma is lightly hoppy, citrus, yeast, malt.  Taste is lightly malty, citrus, light spiciness.

750ml bottle, slight hazy amber-orange hue ,with a thick frothy white head, leaving some laces, yeasty, malty, grainy, fruity nose with a bready dough, faint orange, lemon, peach fruitiness, with a mild floral hop citrusy, and some honeyed pale malt aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, toasty, malty, fruity, spicy character of coriander, some cookie dough, with a touch of honey, great toffee, caramel, and sweet marmalade accents, a good carbonation, with a faint flowery hop citrusy, leading towards a malty, fruity, lingering hop bitterness finish.
pours hazy orange with a nice head.  peppery aroma, with a caramely tone. flavor of pepper and caramel.  not a very complex, refreshing, or engaging brew.  i can have one, but why have more than one?

750ml, 2007 bottling.  Fresh fruit dominates the nose, with hints of pear, melon, white grape, honeysuckle and other floral touches, mildly peppery spice, and some lightly musty, doughy yeast notes in the background.  Light-medium honeyed amber color with a lasting, rocky, off-white head.  Flavor is tangy and lightly tart, with a certain citric, astringent tone throughout to go along with the faint sweetness, mild bitterness and spice, and a drying, herbal, fruity finish that shows a bit of green apple late.  Fizzy and active on the palate with a medium body.  Interesting take on the style, I suppose, if a bit unexciting.

Exquisite bottle.  Golden body with a small gold head.  Aroma is fruity and yeasty with clove and spice.  Flavors match the aroma with some caramel.  A very nice beer but not quite as nice as the bottle.

The pour reveals a cloudy amber color with a thin white head. The aroma is complex and very seductive, malt, spices, fruits and funk tingle my nostrils. The flavor is also very nice, a good, solid malt is joined by fruits, spices and funk, the funk doesnt take all the place in the mouth, its well moderate, theres also some sweetness. The body is medium with a nice creamy texture and the carbonation is soft. This is the first beer I sample from this brewery and Im highly impressed.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez Glouglouburp. Arôme: Odeur de céréale et dépices. Apparence: La couleur est orange voilée. Présence dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dorange et dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût fruité. (Rating #1597)

In short: A juicy and hoppy superior Bière de Garde.
How: Back from Europe tasting session with Montreal crew
The look: Cloudy golden-copper body with a small off-white head
In long: Satisfying blend of cereals, juicy citrusy/orangey hops, olives (!!) with a light but noticeable barnyard character.  Body is slim but pleasant, carbonation is smooth.  Overall rather juicy.  Ha, those Americans, always have to prove they can do what the French are good at and take it to the next level.  The French used to eat French Fries, Americans now eat them twice as much.  The French used to make the best Bière de Garde, Americans now make better ones.  The French used to be the most arrogant chauvinism people and now

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2013 My Bottom Line:
Honest cereals and herbal hops meld into bready yeast in this very drinkable, self-effacing Bière de Garde.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam tops the misty orangey blond.
-Some tangerine-like fruitiness tags along.
-The body is slender and effervescent.
-The overall flavor profile is balanced throughout and rather friendly.

Bottles.

Medium amber body with a light khaki head. Lots of small carbonation bubbles. The aroma is fairly sweet, like unfermented wort. There is also some cake donuts and apples. The mouthfeel is fairly highly carbonated, but its still soft. The taste has bread crust and more unfermented wort. There is also some apple chip character. A decent brew that makes me think about summer.

Objectively speaking:
My first Schlafly. A moment Ive been expecting for years. A rather hoppy example, yet with rich, chewy malts underneath. Americanized, but respectful and masterly crafted.


I like:
Beautiful champaigny looks. Tight white head. Fresh cereal nose. Original pumpkin notes. Spicy display without letting varietals being picked out. Fair dose of herbal hops fit perfectly. Full-bodied, but not thick. Expansive carbonation feels authentic. Very engaging from start to finish.





I dislike:
I like it all. Original and delicious! Not so much yeast nuance, but it just lets the rest shine.

From a beautiful bottle.  Rusty red with a staying wisp of light foam.  The aroma is almost smoky, can it be?  This drinks with a fantasticly rounded complement of fruity esthers, a hint of active yeasts and a base of sweet malt.  This is a beauty. (#3369, 3/31/2008)

Pour is clear amber with a nice tight bubbled off white head...smell is lightly funky but more so of old shoe leather than farmhouse...taste is lightly sweet and also faintly citric with a quick leathery finish...

Bottle... Hazy golden ale with a large, creamy, white head. Decent retention. The aroma is spicy and grainy, providing notes of cornbread, light clove and white pepper. Medium to full-bodied with tingly carbonation. Sweet and spicy, but well-bittered on the backside for an excellent facade of balance. Lengthy, spicy, lightly bitter finish. Stylistically speaking, its spot-on! Thanks go out to xmarcnolanx for the trade!

Hmm am I the only one who thought this was a diacetyl bomb?  Poured a gold copper color with a medium sized white head.  Big diacetyl aroma and flavor with a slippery mouthfeel.  So much that I couldnt concentrate on any redeeming characters it might have.  Sorry.
Bottle courtesy of drmatt.  Pours copper with a white head.  Smells of oranges, roses perfume, some sugar, some grapey hints.  Tastes of pepper, oranges, sugar.  Finish is sweet.

I live less than two hours from the brewery, but its bombers seldom make it to our stores (the stout and barley wine do). I had to go to Kansas City for this one, over four hours from the brewery. Distribution makes so much sense. And its a pity we dont get this when it comes out because it is a good, light, saison-ish beer. Fruity. Bit of banana. Its the kind of beer folks in Missouri should be making - lets shed the pseudo-lager tradition of A-B and see real European styles. And lets help the folks in the smaller towns out too. Send us your good stuff too. 
And maybe, just maybe, Schlafly will do a real old school farmhouse with funky flavors and Belgian yeast.

Pours a hazy, bright orange/amber with a frothy, ivory head that lasts quite a while and laces nicely. The nose is bright and yeasty with notes of dusty farmhouse, soda crackers and faint cotton candy. Light to medium-bodied, it has silky-soft carbonation that transitions to a lightly dry and mildly sour finish. The flavor follows the nose with a yeasty, sour farmhouse character to it that is bright and refreshing. This was my first Bière de Garde, and I now feel compelled to seek out others. This is a tasty and interesting brew; well done. :)
Bottle, thanks to yobdoog.  Yellowish - orange pour.  Aroma is slight funk, some citrus.  The flavor is sweet fruity malt, bubblegum / banana, and some earthiness also.  Pretty good beer.

Thank you drmatt. I really enjoyed this. I like that the alcohol has a bit of a kick. Seems like it enhances the nice fruit flavors (pear, apple, pinapple, banana) and that mellow bitterness. Very smooth candy accents as well from the bold thick caramel malts. Very nice creamy body and mouthfeel. A hint of oil and butter but still good.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2008 Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  The aroma consists of butterscotch, caramel, and faint grain.  It pours a hazy amber with a moderate, quickly fading off-white head.  The flavor starts with butterscotch and fruit.  Theres some faint graininess in the background along with some very faint lemon notes in the finish.  Light-medium bodied with lively carbonation.
Bottle. pours a clear lite orange color with no head. Oily looking brew. Malty with yeasty good sweetness. Light nutty flavors in the finish.
Cloudy dark straw colored pour, scant head.  Nice funky and sour nose.  Palate is light with soft carbonation.  Flavor is somewhat sour and a bit funky.
Lumpfest 2008- medium piss colored with a thin head. Some slight tart citrus mixed with some yeastiness. Not nearly as tasty as the saison.

Dirty orange pour with a big white head.  Aroma of bread, sourdough, orange rind, and earth.  Had a lot to offer on the nose.  Big bready taste, tart with orange and wheaty spices, lemony, grainy.  Very well rounded flavor.  Complex.  Creamy and fluffy mouthfeel with no sharp points to it whatsoever.  I really enjoyed this one!

(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy golden body with a medium off-white head.  Flavor of orange peel, caramel, clove, and light pineapple.  Flavor of clove, orange peel, earthiness, toasted malt, and some tropical fruits (pineapple, banana, papaya).

Aroma is slightly sour, touch of grain.
Taste is slightly grainy also; has a touch of bitterness, but also a nice sweetness.
Very solid flavor with a touch of sourness.  
838416
Pours a murky lighter shade brown.  Aroma is raw grain, a touch of butter, crackers, some caramel, odd.   Flavor is malty and slightly sweet, with that buttery flavor prevailing in the end.

Deep golden orange hues glow in a rich amber body. A medium, frithy head is off-white and quickly receding. Clarity doesnt mesh with preconceived notions of the style at hand. Sweet buttered popcorn brings to light all-too-apparent diacetyl. Beyond that, the aroma is complex and interesting. Caramel is forward and potent, toasted grains fueling the malty fires. Apricot nectar and orange pith are fruity compliments. Peanut brittle is forceful and while pleasing, its a sign of a mismanaged brew. Caramelized brown sugar melts as it leaves the vessel. This is interesting though I dont find it terribly appetizing. Diacetyl is lessened in the flavor as caramel and multiple fruits create a sweet network with a backdrop of tanginess. Acidity is nil, astringency from fruity acids low. The finish is muted, off-dry and caramelly. The mouthfeel is moderately carbonated, smooth and lightly sticky. Average, flawed to a notable degree that detracts from enjoyment at all stages of consumption. The more I drink this, the more I feel like Im drinking water from a goldfish bowl.
UPDATED: JAN 12, 2008 Lumpfest 2008 - malty, spicy scent with a murky gold pour. very sweet and malty.  id have to try this one again for good measure.
Bottle. Sampled at YEHA. Cloudy orange body with nice head. Aroma is buttery, caramel. Flavor is all butter, light caramel. This was bad.

Heres a sweet and malty amber ale whose real depth didnt shine until we washed some turkey down with it. Lovely Christmas treat. Pours dark but bright copper with an off-white head. Malty, cookie-ish nose with loads of sticky caramel and cider notes. Sweet flavor with those biscuit notes and a subtle, lightly bitter, lightly tart edge. Average carbonation. Unbelievable match for the bird.
750ml bottle. Poured a medium and hazy amber color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, spices, and lots of butteriness. Tastes of spices, citrus, butterscotch, and fruity.

Bottle, courtesy of kmweaver. Somewhat cloudy copper-orange with suspended particles and white head. Vanilla, wood, caramel, earthy hops and light pear in the nose. Flavor notes of caramel, orange peel, herbal earthy hops, apple and a little wood. Moderately sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body and carbonation. Solid beer.

(750ml bottle, thanks kmweaver) Lightly hazed light amber body with off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, orange, hay, some funk. Taste is moderately sweet, yeast, straw, some orange.  Somewhat dry finish.  Medium-full body.

750, capped. Thanks, SkoiSirius! Hazy orangey amber with thick fizzy platinum blonde head. Dusty, slightly funky, orange-pith-y nose. Webby lace. Fairly light & fizzy body. Slightly tart candied citrus on the mid-palate. Clean finish. Decent stuff.

Bottle at A&K Holiday tasting brought by Ken, thanks: Slightly hazed coppery hue with a nice frothy head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of old hops and hint of herbal vapours, walnut and almond cookies, sugar, and butterscotch candy. The taste is sweet malt and sugar with a hint of pear and currant fruits. Some spice and herbs toward the finish. The mouth feel is chewy and soft. An okay beer but not to style and has some flaws.

750mL bottle, courtesy of Gregis.  Thanks, Greg!  Pours a hazy, golden-amber color; off-white head with solid lacing.  Doughy, biscuity and butterscotch in the aroma; pleasantly sweet.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: biscuity and toastiness upfront; pleasant, chewy Belgian/estery core with a light perimeter of soft citrus.  Lengthy, doughy and light butterscotch in the finish.
Thanks to Ken for this.  Gold body with a layer of white bubbles.  Buttery, citrus aroma.  Flavors of caramel, honey and butterscotch in a creamy, thick body.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle.  Thick, bright orange; rocky tower of white.  Very sugary aroma of almond creme frosting and honey, with pistachio and pastry crusts; these ride over the top of some must, orange juice and pine essence beneath, with a bit of banana ester.  Flavor brings a slightly buttery kind of sugariness, with pears and melons leading into a more pungent type of sweetness in whole garlic cloves; some green spicing tangentially layering around it.  Bright and sparkly, medium bodied in the mouth.  Plenty of gritty sugars and warming honey in the finish; some age might help to subdue this rough edge, and to tighten the many layers of sweetness which are in general a bit too loose right now.  Thanks for sharing, Ken!
Bottle, 75cl. Hazy orange colour with an off-white head. Fruity & yeasty aroma with hoppy notes. Fruity, citric taste.

Im glad I waited to rate this out of the bottle instead of at Hop in the City this year.  The HitC version was quite sub-par, but out of the bottle it is quite nice.  Pours amber / copper with dancing carbonation and a light tan head.  The aroma is bready with lavender, barnyard funk and smooth caramel malt.  Medium smooth body with some graininess and very soft carbonation.  The flavor starts with nutty malt, light earthy funk, some sweetness, light pepper and rich maltiness.  The finish is a bit citric and medicinal, but the funk is still apparent.  A good biere de garde.

750 mL bottle.  Design on the bottle is pretty cool...  Pour is a darkish amber with a pretty massive two or three finger head of dense foam.  Aromas of wild yeast, spice and light hops that cover a bread dough and earth malt body.  The flavor is dominated by the bread dough malt presence and the tart yeast notes and the spices that were present in the nose are not well developed and almost undetectable at this stage.  Id love to see if these come out as it ages, but doubt Ill get the chance.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: From 750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark golden with a fairly decent large bead head that persists mostly because of the continuous activity of rising bubbles.  Aroma of orange peel, coriander, and hop flowers.  Smooth tart, bready flavor, with some earthy sweet malt character as well.  Citrus juice comes through near the end along with some mild hop bitterness.  I dont know what I expected, but this wasnt it.  This is delicious!  Its similar to so many Belgian and French farm beer offerings, yet not like any of them.  Unique.  Another fine job from the gang at the Tap Room!

750ml bottle poured into a Duvel glass at cellar temperature. Bottle conditioned. Poured a reddish gold. Lots of carbonation, two fingered fine bubbled white head. Spicy aroma with some sweet malt. Light to medium body. A very drinkable beer. Some malt sweetness, spicy yeast flavors.
There are some hop flavors in the finish. Dry finish with more spice.
Very refreshing.

Capped 750ml bottle. I really like the design, btw. Served in a NB snifter outside on a beautiful fall day. Aroma is yeast, corriander?, caramelly sweetness, musty cobwebs, earthiness, and some light fruitiness. The aroma opens more as the beer sits. Amber colored with a small but persistent white head. Initial taste is malty, caramelly & yeasty, with some spicy (black pepper) & earthy (rye) notes following. Full bodied. The finish is malty, but not really sweet. It would seem to be a good example of the style, though it is a style that I am not in love with. Well done, Schlafly.

On-tap at the Taproom, served in a Schlafly Imperial Pint Glass.

A good looking start, cloudy orangey hued tarnished copper with a frothy off-white, creme colored head, good retention, small rings of laced sticking at the top of the glass.

Light whiffs of earthy must, clove and herbal spice, followed by a tart orange and pineapple fruitiness. Estery alcohol and toasted sweet malts at the edges.

Well rounded feel in the palate, airy, creamy moderate body along with a slickness that covers the tongue. Nice spicy flavor in the beginning, earthy must, clove, anise and herbs. Mildly tart fruits, orange, pineapple and banana. A good backbone from the toasted malts, nutty grains with light touches of sweet caramel. In the end, a herbal hop spiciness becomes more pronounced, helping to provide a nice dry finish. The alcohol is barely noticeable, just a nutty, fruity low grade warmth in the mouth.

Lively, fresh taste, I was very impressed by this Bière de Garde, another top notch beer from Schlafly. This is currently on-tap at the Taproom and the Bottleworks, plus 750 ml. bottles are available all over the St. Louis area. I was talking to a couple of patrons at the Taproom who told me they prefer the bottled version over the tap. I am going to pick a case of bottles before I leave St. Louis, I feel confident that this ale will only improve with age.

Tasted 10/19/07.  750ml capped bottle.  Fresh with a lively hiss upon opening.  Large bubbled head.  Bottle conditioned and young.  Moldy layer of off-white head.  Sugary yeast aromas.  Perfumy and bready.  Doughy notes.  Medium bodied and smooth, yet citrusy.  Malty initial flavor with caramel notes.  Then the yeasty citrus candy flavor permeates and dominates the middle.  In closing a peppery anise flavor arises.  Leaving the mouth tingling with a bitter spicy note.  Good drinking now, but a little rough around the edges.  It should meld with age.  Second glass, activated the yeast and resulted in a finger width of dense caverous head.  Sugary yeast nose.  More haze with a darker hue.  More noticeable hop aromas.  They will probally drop off as the beer ages.  Toasty malts and off-dry.  Burn is noticeable yet not overwhelming.  Tight effervescence.  Sticky finish.  Cross of bready and sugary flavors mixed with hop flavors.  Cloying and tangy.  Applaudable take.  Well done!

Draft at Party Source. Poured hazy copper with an average fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate tart citrus yeasty aroma. medium to full body with a soft carbonation and a sticky texture. Medium sweet balanced flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. I would recommend this to a freind.

Bomber bottle.  Pour is a cloudy orange with a average white head.  Aroma is very fruity and yeastey with some barnyard funk.  Flavor is a bit watery but the hops come out tfirst to greet you and that leaves a nice bitterness on the tounge.  Some of the yeast and malts are there but nothing to make a noticable difference.  Slightly above average for the style but its pointing in the right direction.
Had a nice golden color with a medium head.  Had an aroma of fruits and something I couldnt put my finger on.  Ligh yeast and malts in the palate and aroma.  Very light and somewhat watery finish.
(draught - HOP in the City) hazy orange gold with generous white had and nice lace. Aroma of light fruits and yeast. Flavor of light fruits, yeast, slightly sweet
